content:
I've continued to play with enriched categories, and I stumbled upon the following issue.

In usual category theory (Set\text{Set}Set-enriched), the categorical product a×ba \times ba×b can be defined by asking that the presheaf C(_,a)×C(_,b){\cal C}(\_,a) \times {\cal C}(\_, b)C(_,a)×C(_,b) be representable.

Let's try to do the same when C{\cal C}C is a V{\cal V}V-enriched category, with (V,⊗,I)({\cal V}, \otimes, I)(V,⊗,I) a closed monoidal category.
I.e., I'm defining a⊗ba \otimes ba⊗b as a representative of the enriched presheaf C(_,a)⊗C(_,b){\cal C}(\_, a) \otimes {\cal C}(\_, b)C(_,a)⊗C(_,b)

C(z,a⊗b)≅C(z,a)⊗C(z,b) {\cal C}(z, a \otimes b) \cong {\cal C}(z, a) \otimes {\cal C}(z,b)C(z,a⊗b)≅C(z,a)⊗C(z,b)

Of course, it may not exist.

I have two questions:

  1. How does this relate to weighted (co)limits? (I'm aware of the definition of weighted (co)limits)
  2. Is it possible to "freely ⊗\otimes⊗-complete" the category C{\cal C}C?

If V\mathcal{V}V isn't cartesian monoidal, then C(−,a)⊗C(−,b)\mathcal{C}(-,a) \otimes \mathcal{C}(-,b)C(−,a)⊗C(−,b) may not be an enriched presheaf: to define the functorial action, you need diagonals on hom-objects.

Oh, I see, I fell in the trap of not checking functoriality.

I'll spell it out to make it more clear. For F=C(_,a)⊗C(_,b)F = {\cal C}(\_, a) \otimes {\cal C}(\_, b)F=C(_,a)⊗C(_,b) to be functorial, we need, for every x,yx,yx,y, an arrow

C(x,y)→[Fy,Fx] {\cal C}(x,y) \to [Fy, Fx]C(x,y)→[Fy,Fx]

where [_,_][\_,\_][_,_] is the internal hom in V{\cal V}V. And these arrows should be compatible with composition and identities.

Using the tensor hom adjunction, this amounts to define an arrow

C(x,y)⊗C(y,a)⊗C(y,b)→C(x,a)⊗C(x,b){\cal C}(x,y) \otimes {\cal C}(y,a) \otimes {\cal C}(y,b) \to {\cal C}(x,a) \otimes {\cal C}(x,b)C(x,y)⊗C(y,a)⊗C(y,b)→C(x,a)⊗C(x,b)

If we had diagonals

C(x,y)→C(x,y)⊗C(x,y){\cal C}(x,y) \to {\cal C}(x,y) \otimes {\cal C}(x,y)C(x,y)→C(x,y)⊗C(x,y)

and if ⊗\otimes⊗ were symmetric, we could build the above arrow via

C(x,y)⊗C(y,a)⊗C(y,b)→C(x,y)⊗C(x,y)⊗C(y,a)⊗C(y,b)→(C(x,y)⊗C(y,a))⊗(C(x,y)⊗C(y,b))→C(x,a)⊗C(x,b)\begin{align*} &{\cal C}(x,y) \otimes {\cal C}(y,a) \otimes {\cal C}(y,b) \\ &\to {\cal C}(x,y) \otimes {\cal C}(x,y) \otimes {\cal C}(y,a) \otimes {\cal C}(y,b) \\ &\to ({\cal C}(x,y) \otimes {\cal C}(y,a)) \otimes ({\cal C}(x,y) \otimes {\cal C}(y,b)) \\ &\to {\cal C}(x,a) \otimes {\cal C}(x,b) \end{align*}​C(x,y)⊗C(y,a)⊗C(y,b)→C(x,y)⊗C(x,y)⊗C(y,a)⊗C(y,b)→(C(x,y)⊗C(y,a))⊗(C(x,y)⊗C(y,b))→C(x,a)⊗C(x,b)​

But indeed, without the diagonals and the symmetry I can't do that.

Actually, my original context was a bit more involved, and my question above tried to take a short-cut (in vain).
Fortunately, I think my original context doesn't suffer from the flaw above: I do get a functor it seems.
Here it is.

Category Cost\text{Cost}Cost

First, I use Lawvere-like category Cost=((−∞,∞],≥,+,0)\text{Cost} = ((-\infty,\infty], \ge, +, 0)Cost=((−∞,∞],≥,+,0).
Following John's blog post, I also define another tensor product

x∧y=−1βln⁡(e−βx+e−βy) x \wedge y = - \frac{1}{\beta}\ln \Big(e^{-\beta x} + e^{-\beta y}\Big)x∧y=−β1​ln(e−βx+e−βy)

where β>0\beta > 0β>0 is some constant.

It turns out +++ distributes over ∧\wedge∧

x+(y∧z)=(x+y)∧(x+z)x + (y \wedge z) = (x + y) \wedge (x + z)x+(y∧z)=(x+y)∧(x+z)

Category ESet\text{ESet}ESet of energetic sets

This is a slight variant (I think) of John's energetic sets from a previous thread.

  • objects are sets XXX with an energy function E:X→CostE : X \to \text{Cost}E:X→Cost
  • morphisms are functions f:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y such that E(x)≥E(f(x))E(x) \ge E(f(x))E(x)≥E(f(x)) (energy-decreasing)

Tensor product ⊗\otimes⊗

I define a first symmetric tensor product

X⊗Y≜(X×Y,(x,y)↦E(x)+E(y)) X \otimes Y \triangleq (X \times Y, (x,y) \mapsto E(x) + E(y))X⊗Y≜(X×Y,(x,y)↦E(x)+E(y))

with the unit I=({∙},∙↦0)I = (\{\bullet\}, \bullet \mapsto 0)I=({∙},∙↦0).
I write x⊗yx \otimes yx⊗y the pair (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) considered as an element of X⊗YX \otimes YX⊗Y.

This tensor product is closed.
The internal hom [Y,Z][Y,Z][Y,Z] is the set of functions f:Y→Zf : Y \to Zf:Y→Z with energy

E(f)=sup⁡y (E(f(y))−E(y))E(f) = \sup_y ~ (E(f(y)) - E(y))E(f)=ysup​ (E(f(y))−E(y))

Tensor product ∧\wedge∧

I define a second symmetric tensor product

X∧Y≜(X×Y,(x,y)↦E(x)∧E(y))X \wedge Y \triangleq (X \times Y, (x,y) \mapsto E(x) \wedge E(y))X∧Y≜(X×Y,(x,y)↦E(x)∧E(y))

with the unit ∞=(∙,∙↦∞)\infty = ({\bullet}, \bullet \mapsto \infty)∞=(∙,∙↦∞).
I write x∧yx \wedge yx∧y the pair (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) considered as an element of X∧YX \wedge YX∧Y.

It turns out the ∧\wedge∧-diagonals X→X∧XX \to X \wedge XX→X∧X exist. It maps x↦x∧xx \mapsto x \wedge xx↦x∧x.
The energy inequality is satisfied

E(x∧x)=E(x)∧E(x)=E(x)−ln⁡2β≤E(x)\begin{align*} E(x \wedge x) &= E(x) \wedge E(x) \\ &= E(x) - \frac{\ln 2}{\beta} \\ &\le E(x) \end{align*}E(x∧x)​=E(x)∧E(x)=E(x)−βln2​≤E(x)​

Almost distributive

Because both ⊗\otimes⊗ and ∧\wedge∧ have as underlying set the cartesian product of the respective sets, ⊗\otimes⊗ does not distribute over ∧\wedge∧.

But, thanks to the diagonal, we have a morphism

X⊗(Y∧Z)→(X⊗Y)∧(X⊗Z)X \otimes (Y \wedge Z) \to (X \otimes Y) \wedge (X \otimes Z)X⊗(Y∧Z)→(X⊗Y)∧(X⊗Z)

with energy equality E(x⊗(y∧z))=E((x⊗y)∧(x⊗z))E(x \otimes (y \wedge z)) = E((x \otimes y) \wedge (x \otimes z))E(x⊗(y∧z))=E((x⊗y)∧(x⊗z)).

Finally

I consider ESet\text{ESet}ESet with the monoidal structure (⊗,I)(\otimes, I)(⊗,I) as an enriching category.
Let C{\cal C}C be a ESet\text{ESet}ESet-enriched category.
Roughly speaking, C{\cal C}C is like a usual locally small category, but each arrow has "an energy cost", and the costs add up when composition.

Now, I can use the second tensor product to define

F=C(z,a)∧C(z,b) F = {\cal C}(z,a) \wedge {\cal C}(z,b)F=C(z,a)∧C(z,b)

Thanks to the properties above, I think FFF is indeed a ESet\text{ESet}ESet-enriched presheaf.

And I was wondering about the representability of FFF,

C(z,a∧b)≅C(z,a)∧C(z,b){\cal C}(z, a \wedge b) \cong {\cal C}(z,a) \wedge {\cal C}(z,b)C(z,a∧b)≅C(z,a)∧C(z,b)

I have to say, I'm having a good share of fun in trying to interpret this weird operation ∧\wedge∧, but I'll stop here for now.
That's a lot to post in one go!

Yes sorry about that. It was late in the night when I replied, and, as the joke says, "I didn't have time to make it shorter" :upside_down:

Here is a shorter reformulation.

Let (V,⊗,I)({\cal V}, \otimes, I)(V,⊗,I) be a closed symmetric monoidal category, and C{\cal C}C a V{\cal V}V-enriched category.
Assume there is another symmetric monoidal structure (V,∧,∞)({\cal V}, \wedge, \infty)(V,∧,∞) on V{\cal V}V which has diagonals X→X∧XX \to X \wedge XX→X∧X, and such that we have "distributivity natural morphisms" (not iso)

X⊗(Y∧Z)→(X⊗Y)∧(X⊗Z)X \otimes (Y \wedge Z) \to (X \otimes Y) \wedge (X \otimes Z)X⊗(Y∧Z)→(X⊗Y)∧(X⊗Z)

Then,

F=C(_,a)∧C(_,b)F = {\cal C}(\_,a) \wedge {\cal C}(\_, b)F=C(_,a)∧C(_,b)

defines (I think) an enriched presheaf. If FFF were representable, there would exist some object a∧ba \wedge ba∧b such that C(_,a∧b)≅C(_,a)∧C(_,b){\cal C}(\_, a \wedge b) \cong {\cal C}(\_, a) \wedge {\cal C}(\_, b)C(_,a∧b)≅C(_,a)∧C(_,b).

My original questions were:

  • How does this "limit object" a∧ba \wedge ba∧b relate to weighted (co)limits?
  • Is it possible to "freely ∧\wedge∧-complete" C{\cal C}C so that this functor becomes representable?
I don't think this object is going to be a weighted limit of any sort.
To freely complete, you could probably do some iterative construction.
